L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: In assessing the Child’s best interests, the Court considers the totality of the circumstances, including, without limitation, the Child’s age and developmental needs, the stability of each household, the relationship between the Child and each parent, the ability of each parent to meet the Child’s needs, and the necessity of a schedule that supports the Child’s education, health, and emotional stability.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: The requested modification is consistent with Massachusetts statutes and caselaw emphasizing the child’s best interests, the importance of a stable and predictable schedule, and the Court’s broad equitable power to adjust parenting arrangements when circumstances materially change.

**Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The Child’s increased age, developmental stage, and school obligations materially alter the circumstances that existed at the time of the prior order, when the Child was only three (3) years old and not in full‑time school.
**Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss material and substantial change in circumstances for custody modification, but it focuses on work schedules, relocation, temporary custody orders, and extended family—not on the child’s increased age, developmental stage, or school obligations as independent grounds for material change. In fact, the court finds no material and substantial change warranting modification since the prior order, despite the child’s being in school and subject to a different weekly routine. Thus it does not support the proposition that the child’s older age and school obligations materially altered the prior circumstances.
**Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle….’ … There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements…. To the contrary, the findings reflect that the mother is a loving and appropriate caretaker.”

**Smith v. McDonald**, 458 Mass. 540 (20.proposition: The Child’s increased age, developmental stage, and school obligations materially alter the circumstances that existed at the time of the prior order, when the Child was only three (3) years old and not in full‑time school.
**Smith v. McDonald**, 458 Mass. 540 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion is about statutory interpretation in a paternity/relocation context and the limits on a judge’s authority to order a custodial mother to return to Massachusetts after she lawfully relocated before paternity was adjudicated. It does not address modification standards based on a child’s increased age, developmental stage, or school obligations, nor does it discuss changed circumstances tied to a transition from preschool age to full‑time school. The proposition concerning material change due to the child’s age and schooling is therefore not supported by this case.
**Smith v. McDonald**, 458 Mass. 540 (20.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. … The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts.”

**Murray v. Super**, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 1.proposition: The principal factual basis for the original “no overnight” restriction—Father’s lack of appropriate, stable child‑suitable housing—no longer exists.
**Murray v. Super**, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 1.support_reasoning: The Murray v. Super opinion concerns removal of children from the Commonwealth and modification of child support. It does not discuss any prior "no overnight" restriction, the factual basis for such a restriction, or any change in the father’s housing or its suitability for overnight parenting time. Because the issue of father’s housing stability and an overnight restriction is not addressed at all, the case cannot support the specific proposition stated.
**Murray v. Super**, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 1.relevant_excerpt: "The children are with the father on alternating weekends from Friday evening to Monday morning and overnight each Wednesday. The father has additional parenting time in the summer and on some holidays. The remaining time is spent with the mother." (87 Mass. App. Ct. at 147 n.3).

**Fugere v. Fugere**, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The principal factual basis for the original “no overnight” restriction—Father’s lack of appropriate, stable child‑suitable housing—no longer exists.
**Fugere v. Fugere**, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns modification of alimony and child support based on changes in income, expenses, and emancipation of a child. It does not involve any parenting-time or “no overnight” restriction, nor does it discuss housing conditions as a basis for such a restriction. Therefore, this case provides no authority for the proposition that the factual basis for a prior no‑overnight order (inadequate housing) no longer exists.
**Fugere v. Fugere**, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In the instant matter, two factors could provide some support for the judge’s conclusion that there had been a material change in the parties’ circumstances — the emancipation of David … and the wife’s additional income through part-time employment.”

**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.proposition: The existing schedule, designed for a pre‑school‑aged child, has become ill‑suited to the realities of an eight‑year‑old in full‑time school and is no longer in the Child’s best interests.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns relocation of children to Greece and standards for removal and custody, not modification of an existing parenting-time schedule due to a child’s age or school demands. Nowhere does the court discuss a pre‑school‑age schedule becoming inappropriate for an eight‑year‑old in full‑time school, nor does it analyze or hold that an existing schedule is no longer in the child’s best interests for that reason. Thus the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

**Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003.proposition: The existing schedule, designed for a pre‑school‑aged child, has become ill‑suited to the realities of an eight‑year‑old in full‑time school and is no longer in the Child’s best interests.
**Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss modification of an existing, preschool‑oriented schedule that has become unsuitable for an older, school‑aged child. Instead, it affirms an original custody and visitation allocation structured around the child’s school year and vacations, based on best‑interests and statutory factors under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a). There is no holding or reasoning about an existing preschool schedule becoming ill‑suited once the child reaches full‑time school age, so the case does not support the specific proposition stated.
**Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003.relevant_excerpt: “The judge awarded legal custody of Kali to the mother, and divided physical custody between the father and the mother corresponding with the school year and vacations. During the school year, Kali was to reside principally with her mother, with the father having custody of her three weekends a month. During the summer, Kali was to reside principally with her father, with the mother having custody every other weekend. School vacation periods were to be split between the mother and the father.”

**Adoption of Hugo**, 428 Mass. 219 (199.proposition: While a child’s preferences are not controlling, they are a relevant factor under Massachusetts law in assessing the Child’s best interests, especially as a child matures.
**Adoption of Hugo**, 428 Mass. 219 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses multiple best-interests factors (stability, sibling relationships, bonding, developmental needs, etc.), but it does not address, even indirectly, the role of the child’s own stated preferences. Hugo was a very young child, and the court never mentions taking his wishes into account or articulating any rule about children’s expressed preferences as a factor in the best-interests analysis. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the proposition that a child’s preferences, while not controlling, are a relevant factor, especially as the child matures.
**Adoption of Hugo**, 428 Mass. 219 (199.relevant_excerpt: "Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’ ... [A] judge may consider a wide range of permissible evidence in determining which placement will serve the child’s best interests."

**Custody of Zia**, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 23.proposition: While a child’s preferences are not controlling, they are a relevant factor under Massachusetts law in assessing the Child’s best interests, especially as a child matures.
**Custody of Zia**, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 23.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the general Massachusetts ‘best interests of the child’ standard and various statutory and factual factors, but it does not address or analyze the role of the child’s own custodial preferences at all. There is no mention of the child’s wishes, maturity, or the weight to be given to a child’s preference. Accordingly, this case cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that a child’s preferences are a relevant (though not controlling) best‑interests factor as the child matures.
**Custody of Zia**, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 23.relevant_excerpt: “[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . . A judge may consider any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the dispute.” (The opinion then lists factors such as parental communication, judgment, and involvement, but does not mention the child’s preferences.)

**Schuler v. Schuler**, 382 Mass. 366 (1.proposition: These changes were not anticipated at the time of the original order in the specific form they have developed, and their cumulative effect is substantial and material, warranting modification under Massachusetts law.
**Schuler v. Schuler**, 382 Mass. 366 (1.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that unanticipated, cumulatively substantial changes in circumstances can warrant modification under Massachusetts law. Schuler does restate the general rule that a material change in circumstances is required for modification, but the Court ultimately finds no material change and affirms denial of modification. The opinion does not focus on whether the particular changes were or were not anticipated at the time of the original order, nor does it treat the cumulative changes here as sufficient; instead it holds the opposite, that the changes did not warrant modification. Thus it cannot fairly be cited as authority that such cumulative, unanticipated changes warrant modification.
**Schuler v. Schuler**, 382 Mass. 366 (1.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In this case, the judge held that Chester did not prove the requisite change of circumstances. … Thus, regardless of Chester’s current employment status, we conclude that the evidence as a whole warranted the finding that he retained the ability to continue to make the payments required by the judgment.”

**Cooper v. Cooper**, 99 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: These changes were not anticipated at the time of the original order in the specific form they have developed, and their cumulative effect is substantial and material, warranting modification under Massachusetts law.

**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (200.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that the moving party in a custody/parenting‑time modification must show: (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment; and (2) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.
**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (200.support_reasoning: The case is a removal/relocation decision under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in the context of an existing joint custody arrangement, not a general custody/parenting‑time modification case applying the two‑part ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ plus ‘best interests’ test. The opinion does not state that a party seeking modification must first demonstrate a material and substantial change in circumstances; instead, it focuses directly on whether removal is in the children’s best interests under the removal statute. Thus it does not support the claimed proposition about the general standard for modification proceedings.
**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (200.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that “[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.” “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.” Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.

**Bouchard v. Bouchard**, 12 Mass. App..proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that the moving party in a custody/parenting‑time modification must show: (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment; and (2) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.
**Bouchard v. Bouchard**, 12 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the standards for an original custody determination in a divorce judgment, focusing entirely on the requirement that custody decisions be based on the welfare/best interests of the child. It does not involve or discuss a complaint for modification, nor does it mention any requirement of showing a material and substantial change in circumstances since a prior judgment. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the two‑part standard governing custody/parenting‑time modification proceedings.
**Bouchard v. Bouchard**, 12 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.”

**Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (19.proposition: In assessing the Child’s best interests, the Court considers the totality of the circumstances, including, without limitation, the Child’s age and developmental needs, the stability of each household, the relationship between the Child and each parent, the ability of each parent to meet the Child’s needs, and the necessity of a schedule that supports the Child’s education, health, and emotional stability.
**Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its impact on the child when making custody decisions, and references the statutory ‘best interests’ framework, but it does not articulate a comprehensive, multi‑factor best‑interests test of the kind described in the proposition. While it acknowledges considering the child’s preference, school performance, and parental conduct, it does not set out or endorse a list including age, developmental needs, household stability, and scheduling needs for education, health, and emotional stability. Thus it only indirectly reflects best‑interests considerations and does not serve as authority for the full, specific multi‑factor standard claimed.
**Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (19.relevant_excerpt: “The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother … and the effect of this abuse on the child… We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication.”
